Issues.Title: build: improve error message for upgrade test helper
Issues.Body:
Currently whenever the upgrade test helper fails to load a given AngularJS version, the error that will be rejected is technically not an error because the `onerror` callback is not returning an error, but an "ErrorEvent".

Since that `ErrorEvent` is basically just rejected, browsers will print the error as followed:

```
Failed: [object Event]
```

This is not helpful at all and also implies that there _might_ be more information hidden within the `Event` instance. Unfortunately that's not the case (at least on browsers we test against) and the logic to extract the data from the event would be not worth the effort, we just return a simple custom `Error` that won't imply that there is more information hidden.

Issues.Title: feat(ivy): implement listing lazy routes in `ngtsc`
Issues.Body:
## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [x] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [ ] ~~Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)~~


## PR Type
- [x] Feature
- [x] Build related changes


## What is the current behavior?
`ngtsc` does not support `listLazyRoutes()`, which the cli uses to split code into bundles.

Jira issue: FW-629


## What is the new behavior?
`ngtsc` does support listing all lazy routes. It still does not support listing routes for a specific entry point (but I am not sure if it is necessary with Ivy - see "More information" below).


## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No


## More information
Listing lazy routes for a specific entry point seems to only be needed in `jit` mode and only when `entryModule` is defined ([source](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/851d6948a45cd59821c93e262eff242a6947f491/packages/ngtools/webpack/src/angular_compiler_plugin.ts#L428-L441)).
`entryModule` is only defined if it is explicitly specified in option ([source](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/851d6948a45cd59821c93e262eff242a6947f491/packages/ngtools/webpack/src/angular_compiler_plugin.ts#L306-L311)) or when not in Ivy ([source](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/851d6948a45cd59821c93e262eff242a6947f491/packages/ngtools/webpack/src/angular_compiler_plugin.ts#L409)).

From what I understand from [here](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/914f99d75e6c44bd611fac817418132104b8e846/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/angular-cli-files/models/webpack-configs/typescript.ts#L72-L87), `options/compilerOptions` will never specify `entryModule`, so listing lazy routes for specific entry points will never be required when `enableIvy` is truthy.

<sub>Still possible I have missed some edgecase, where `entryModule` is defined (in some non-straight-forward way).</sub>

Issues.Title: Better log output for Saucelabs connect tunnel
Issues.Body:
Jobs which are unable to even establish a Saucelabs tunnel instance, just print out dots for 10 minutes until Travis terminates the job.

This is not helpful because usually this happens if the API rate limit has been exceeded, and it would be good to log this into the console. Additionally it might be good to add a timeout of ~2 minutes since we don't want Travis to terminate the job, and rather print the log output before exiting.

See: https://travis-ci.org/angular/angular/jobs/468233060#L692

We might be able to just re-add a log file by using `stdout` and `stderr` instead of the Saucelabs `--logfile` option (as this is always verbose and can overwhelm travis)

```

Your global Angular CLI version (7.1.3) is greater than your local
version (7.1.2). The local Angular CLI version is used.

To disable this warning use "ng config -g cli.warnings.versionMismatch false".
```

The ng CLI should just use the locally installed version if it exists, this solves any problems with mismatching. If the user really wants to force the usage of the global version, then a simple flag would be nice:

```
ng build --force-global-cli-version
```

The basic algorithm would be:

1. Find project root (nearest package.json when walking the tree)
2. Looking for the corresponding file `node_modules/.bin/ng`
3. If that file exists launch that one instead of using $(which ng)

Of course it's pretty much the same file in two different locations, so you will need a flag. Alternatively, the bash script could be responsible for locating a .js file and once you find the right js file you just run node ng.js

Issues.Body:
```
- [x] bug report -> please search issues before submitting
- [x] feature request
```

Currently, if an option is marked as required in the schema the schematics CLI will error if no value is passed for that option in non-interactive mode. However, if you are interactive mode and don't provide a value for a required option at its prompt, it is interpreted as having the "value" of the empty string.

You can work around this by adding validation to your schema to not accept the empty string, but that defeats the purpose / convenience of marking options as required.

Prompts should reject the empty string as a value for required options.

Issues.Title: fix(menu): accidentally tapping on sub-menu content that overlaps trigger on touch devices
Issues.Body:
We depend on the `mouseenter` event to switch between sub-menus, both on touch and mouse devices. Since `mouseenter` is emulated on touch devices, it fires much earlier in the event chain which means that the sub-menu can be shown before the user has lifted their finger. This can be an issue if the sub-menu overlaps the trigger in which case a click will be triggered on the content. These changes fix the issue by re-using an earlier fix that blocks interactions with the panel while it's animating.

Note: an alternate approach can be to do something something similar to what we did with the ripples where we block `mouseenter` for a period after the last `touchstart` event. The problem of doing so is that it'll block all `mouseenter` events on touch devices which we depend on to toggle the panel when switching from one sub-menu to another.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(menu): accidentally tapping on sub-menu content that overlaps trigger on touch devices" (#14538)

Issues.Title: fix(bottom-sheet): bottom-sheet content not being read out by screen readers
Issues.Body:
Currently we focus the first focusable element inside a bottom sheet as per the accessibility recommendations, however moving focus to the first item causes some screen readers not to read out the rest of the bottom sheet content. These changes switch to focusing the bottom sheet container by default which allows screen readers to read out everything. If users press tab, they'll land on the first tabbable element anyways. The old behavior can still be opted into via the autoFocus option.

Relates to #10591.

**Note:** these changes are along the same lines as #14533. I'm splitting them into a separate PR to make the sync easier.
